Fig. 5 Grubbs and Hoveyda-Grubbs catalysts for pyridine derivative synthesis: Probing the mechanistic pathways using DFT Premaja R. Remya Cherumuttathu H. Suresh ⁎ Chemical Sciences and Technology Division, Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research-AcSIR, CSIR-National Institute for Interdisciplinary Science and Technology, Thiruvananthapuram, 695019, India Chemical Sciences and Technology Division Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research-AcSIR CSIR-National Institute for Interdisciplinary Science and Technology Thiruvananthapuram 695019 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Mechanistic study on the cyclotrimerization of a diyne and nitrile to pyridine derivative catalyzed by Grubbs and Hoveyda catalysts. The [2 + 2 + 2] cyclotrimerization of diynes and nitrile provides an efficient method for the synthesis of pyridine and its derivatives which can be extended in the total synthesis of natural products. Use of Grubbs type ruthenium catalysts in the cyclotrimerization reaction expands the applicability of Ru(II) catalysts. Two plausible pathways, viz. metathesis and non-metathesis for the cyclotrimerization reaction between a diyne and a nitrile are elucidated with Grubbs second generation and Hoveyda-Grubbs catalysts using DFT techniques. A ruthenacyclobutene like complex is obtained as a stable intermediate in the metathesis pathway while the formation of a five membered metallacycle is invoked to explain the non-metathesis pathway using a decomposed catalyst. The study reveals the influence of N-substituents on N-heterocyclic ligands (NHC) as well as substituent on carbene ligand in controlling the energetic of both metathesis and non-metathesis pathways. Incorporating NHC ligand with reduced steric influence in catalyst design is desirable for improving the efficiency of cyclotrimerization reaction of alkynes with nitriles. If the catalyst is not decomposed, metathesis is the reaction route and the preferred product will be a benzene derivative. The heterocycle formation observed by Pérez-Castells et al. (Org. Lett., 14, 2012, 4982–4985) in presence of excess activated nitriles can only be described using the decomposed catalyst through a non-metathesis pathway. Keywords Cyclotrimerization reaction Density functional theory Pyridine synthesis Grubbs catalyst 1 Introduction The [2 + 2 + 2] cyclotrimerization of alkynes and nitriles catalyzed by transition metal complexes provides an efficient and atom economic strategy for the synthesis of a wide variety of substituted hetero-aromatic compounds [1–11]. This strategy for the pyridine derivative synthesis found application in the total synthesis of many natural products and pharmaceutically important molecules [12–18]. Among the transition metals, cobalt complexes found to effectively catalyze the [2 + 2 + 2] cyclotrimerization reaction [5,19–21]. Later ruthenium-based catalysts are also used for the cyclotrimerization reaction of alkynes and nitriles [22–26]. Based on experimental and theoretical results, a mechanism has been proposed for the cyclotrimerization reaction involving the formation of a metallacylopentadiene intermediate (Scheme 1 ) [25,27–31]. According to this mechanism, the metal center can accommodate two alkyne units which promote CC bond coupling between them leading to the formation of a metallacycle intermediate. In the next step, the nitrile coordinates to the metal center. The coordinated nitrile couples with the metal-carbon bond of metallacylopentadiene to form a bicyclic product which opens up to a seven-membered ring and subsequently changes to a six-membered aromatic heterocycle [1,5,32]. Blechert and Peters were the first to use Grubbs first generation catalysts for the cyclotrimerization of alkynes to benzene derivatives [33]. They proposed a mechanism consisting of four metathesis steps involving a metallacyclobutene intermediate. Later, synthesis of aromatic systems via [2 + 2 + 2] cyclotrimerization reaction of alkynes was reported using Grubbs first generation catalyst [4,34–36]. All these reports suggest a cascade of metatheses as a possible pathway for the cyclotrimerization reaction. Scheme 2 depicts the cyclotrimerization of two alkynes and nitrile to pyridine using ruthenium carbene catalysts in a metathesis pathway passing through the metallacyclobutene intermediate. Recently many researchers have reported the use of Grubbs second generation and Hoveyda-Grubbs catalysts for the [2 + 2 + 2] cyclotrimerization reactions of alkynes with various substrates such as alkynes, nitriles, alkenes [10,37–41]. Though Grubbs ruthenium catalysts are well known for their efficiency to make new CC bonds via metathesis pathway [42,43], it is observed that under special reaction conditions, the Grubbs catalysts can catalyze non-metathesis reactions such as olefin isomerization, cycloaddition, etc. which are often found as side reactions during metathesis [44–47]. These reactions widen the application of ruthenium carbene catalyst in synthetic chemistry. It is observed that Grubbs catalyst undergoes decomposition in strong reaction condition and thus formed modified system can catalyze non-metathesis type reactions [48–50]. Pérez-Castells group used Grubbs second generation catalyst in the cyclotrimerization of diynes with alkynes, where they reported a modification of Grubbs system for the formation of a catalytically active non-carbenic species [10,38,40]. They later developed a new synthetic strategy for the pyridine derivative synthesis by the cyclotrimerization of a diyne with nitriles (Scheme 3 ) using Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst [26]. Their reaction typically happened at high temperature (90 °C) and in presence of excess amount of activated nitrile (5 equivalents with respect to diyne). They also reported the formation of a benzene derivative with some diyne systems due to oligomerization. This reaction is important since it can be used in the total synthesis of natural products with nitrogen containing heterocycles. Though pyridine derivative synthesis using transition metal complexes [51–54] is already known, use of Grubbs catalyst system in the cyclotrimerization is significant as the catalyst is well-known for its stability and functional group tolerance [42]. In this study, the reaction between a dipropargyl ether and acetonitrile leading to the formation of a heterocycle molecule using Hoveyda-Grubbs catalysts and Grubbs second generation catalyst are considered for a detailed study on the mechanistic aspects covering both metathesis and non-metathesis pathways. In a recent work, we addressed the acetylene cyclotrimerization to benzene, catalyzed by Grubbs first and second generation catalysts [55]. Here we are extending the scope of the cyclotrimerization reaction to an experimentally reported reaction of a pyridine heterocycle formation using the Hoveyda-Grubbs and Grubbs second generation catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first attempt to understand the mechanistic pathways of the pyridine ring formation using these catalysts. 2 Computational section Optimization and frequency calculations of all the molecules are done at the BP86/BS1 level [56,57] of density functional theory (DFT) using Gaussian09 program [58]. In BS1, ruthenium center is defined with LANL2DZ basis set and pseudopotentials for core electrons while 6–31G(d) basis set is used to define all other atoms. All the transition states are characterized by a single imaginary frequency along the reaction coordinate, whereas all the intermediates are confirmed to be a minimum by locating zero imaginary frequency in the vibrational analysis. Further, single point calculation in dichloromethane is done using the SMD model [59] at the BP86-D2/BS2 level to understand the dispersion and solvation effect on the total energy. In BS2, the metal center is defined using LANL2DZ with f polarization and pseudopotentials for core electrons whereas the lighter elements are defined using 6–31 + G(d,p) basis set. The Gibbs free energy of every system is estimated by adding the thermal correction to Gibbs free energy calculated at BP86/BS1 level and the total energy obtained at BP86-D2/BS2 level. The Gibbs free energies are calculated at the standard reaction conditions, viz. temperature 298.15 K and pressure 1 atm. 3 Results and discussion Four catalyst models, 1–4 (Fig. 1 ) are selected for this study. 1 is the Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst [60,61] characterized by the isopropoxy unit and the bulky N-heterocyclic ligand in the coordination environment of Ru. 2 is Grubbs second generation catalyst [62] with the typical PCy3 as the labile ligand. Catalyst models 3 and 4 are the smaller versions of 1 and 2 respectively with a methyl group on the NHC nitrogen. In 4, the labile ligand is PMe3. Reducing the ligand bulk has only a minor influence on the geometrical parameters of the catalysts (Fig. 1). The steric interaction between the bulky mesityl groups and chloro ligands keeps the NHC ring coplanar with the ruthenium carbene bond in 1 and 2 while in the case of 3 and 4, the reduced steric influence promotes orientation of NHC ring towards the direction of chloro ligands. Both metathesis (Scheme 2) and non-metathesis (Scheme 1) pathways are modelled using all the four catalyst models and are discussed below 3.1 Pathway 1: metathesis pathway Fig. 2 shows various intermediates and transition states formed in the metathesis pathway using Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst 1. For all the catalysts, a dissociative mechanism is considered for the metathesis [63,64]. In the case of 1, the ruthenium oxygen bond cleaves to get an active form of the catalyst 1′. To 1′, one of the CC triple bonds from the diyne coordinates by a bottom bound attack to form 1a. CC bond coupling between CC triple bond and ruthenium carbene bond occurs in the next step via 1ts1 which yields the ruthenacyclobutene like intermediate 1b. Here the triple bond coordination and CC coupling resemble the mechanism of enyne metathesis, a reaction that describes the formation of a 1,3-diene due to the coupling of an alkene and an alkyne in presence of a catalyst [65,66]. Though ruthenacyclobutene is not reported as intermediate in enyne metathesis, η3 vinyl carbene ruthenium complexes are identified in the mechanism [67–69]. Here 1b possesses a non planar structure while the metallacycles reported for olefin and alkyne metathesis exhibit planar structure due to 1,3-metal-carbon bonding interactions [70]. In 1b, RuCα bond distance for the saturated Cα is 2.14 Å and for the other Cα is 1.90 Å suggesting that the former could undergo RuC bond rupture to yield the intermediate 1c. The ether oxygen functionality of 1c shows coordination to the metal center (RuO distance 2.35 Å) and suggests that 1c largely retains the structural and electronic properties of the Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst. 1c has a four-membered oxygen incorporated metallacycle while that in the original catalyst is five-membered. In the next metathesis step, the second alkyne bond of diyne coordinates to the metal by replacing the RuO interaction (1d). 1d has a distorted trigonal bipyramidal configuration with chloro ligands at the apical position and the ClRuCl bond angle changes from 160° in 1c to 169° in 1d. The second CC bond coupling occurs via 1ts2. The product of this reaction 1e resembles that of the active form of a typical Grubbs second generation catalyst. Here a metallacycle formation is not observed which may be attributed to the ring strain effect. In the next step, acetonitrile coordinates to 1e through its nitrogen (1f) and subsequently undergoes insertion into the ruthenium carbene bond via the transition state 1ts3. The product of this step 1g shows a short RuN bond of distance 1.83 Å. This indicates double bond character to RuN bond and the formation of a ruthenium nitrene complex. Fourth metathesis step is a ring closing step, where the alkene functionality adjacent to the phenyl ring (formed in the first metathesis step) coordinates to the metal (1h) and couples with RuN bond to give the transition state 1ts4. 1ts4 yields a heterometallacycle 1i which subsequently undergoes a CC bond rupture via 1ts5 to produce the pyridine derivative 1j which is coordinated to the ruthenium center. Grubbs second generation catalyst 2 follows the reaction in a way similar to that given in Fig. 2. The labile phosphine ligand dissociates from the catalyst to get an active form of the catalyst 2′. The intermediates and transition states formed in the metathesis trimerization pathway by 2 are very similar to that of 1 and, are given in the Supplementary Material. Also, smaller versions of 1 and 2, viz. 3 and 4 follow the metathesis reaction pathway in the same way as shown in Fig. 2. Irrespective of the ligands, the intermediates and transition states located in the reaction pathways are very similar. Reaction energy profiles for the trimerization reaction via metathesis pathway using all the four catalysts are given in Fig. 3 . These profiles show highly exothermic character of the reaction as the triple bonds are converted to aromatic bonds. The RuO bond dissociation requires 4.9 and 4.7 kcal/mol in 1 and 3. The phosphine ligand dissociation from 2 and 4 requires 16.2 and 11.5 kcal/mol respectively. Once the active form of the catalyst is formed, alkyne coordinates in the vacant space. Metathesis reaction pathway of the Hoveyda-Grubbs-type catalyst models shows a slight difference in the energy profile compared to that of Grubbs second generation catalysts. Since 1 and 3 has bulky group attached to the carbene carbon, the alkyne coordination experiences a steric hindrance, and thus a high energy is noted in the reaction profile for the alkyne coordination. The reaction profiles in Fig. 3 clearly indicate that the ligand bulk on the carbene carbon has significant influence on the first two cross metathesis steps. Nitrile coordination and further coupling reactions are influenced by the ligand bulk on the NHC. Activation barrier for the first cross metathesis (ts1) is in the range 5.5–9.9 kcal/mol while the second cross metathesis (ts2) barrier is in the range 7.1–12.0 kcal/mol. The bulky catalysts 1 and 2 show smaller activation barrier in both first and second metathesis steps compared to their smaller analogue. The third metathesis (ts3) involving the CN bond coupling is a high energy demanding process (∼30.0 kcal/mol) for all catalysts. The final ring closing metathesis step (ts4) has an activation barrier of 28.4, 30.5, 6.6, and 4.6 respectively for 1, 2, 3 and 4. The CC coupling defined by ts4 leads to a metallacycle structure i for all. The metallacycle i, opens up immediately to form the final product j and the activation barrier required for the ring opening is in the range 3.3–4.9 kcal/mol. Though the synthesis of pyridine and pyridone type molecules via metathesis based approach is already reported [36,71,72], the present study is the first one on mechanistic aspects that unravels a cascade of metatheses for pyridine synthesis. In the mechanism, the metallacyclobutene structure b is clearly seen as an intermediate in all the catalyst models which opens up to an active catalyst c in a barrier less process. The minimum energy state of 1b is also validated by locating its structure using different DFT methods (Supplementary Material) since the stability of metallacyclobutene like structure is often debated in enyne metathesis. The rate limiting step of the reaction is the CC bond coupling between carbon of acetonitrile and Cα of the catalyst (via ts3) for the smaller catalysts models (∼30 kcal/mol). For the bulky catalysts models 1 and 2, the final RCM is a high energy process (∼30 kcal/mol). In all the f intermediates, end-on coordination of acetonitrile yields the most stable complex than side-on coordination, which promotes the CC coupling via ts3 to form an active catalyst g. 3.2 Pathway 2: non-metathesis pathway Cyclotrimerization via non-metathesis pathway can occur after a catalyst modification. Decomposition of Grubbs catalysts has been reported under strong reaction condition,[48,73] and thus formed modified catalysts are assumed to catalyze the non-metathesis type reactions which often observed as a side reaction during metathesis. Although such a modified catalyst is not yet characterized, reports suggest that the metathesis active ruthenium carbene bond does not exist in the modified catalyst [38,74,75] Many decomposition pathways have been reported for Grubbs type catalysts both experimentally and theoretically. Mol and coworkers were the first to report such a decomposition of ruthenium carbene based complexes to a highly active ruthenium hydride system [76,77]. Substrate induced decomposition of Grubbs ruthenium carbene system has been proposed to occur either by α or β-hydride transfer.[48,73,78,79] Grubbs group reported the thermal decomposition of phosponium based Grubbs catalyst to a dinuclear ruthenium hydride complex [49]. They proposed that the dissociated phosphine ligand can attack the nucleophilic methylidene center of the catalyst to form a ruthenium hydride complex [49]. Decomposition of a Z-selective ruthenium metathesis catalysts have been attempted by Grubbs, Houk and coworkers using X-ray crystallography and density functional theory [80]. Fogg et al. reported a donor induced decomposition of Grubbs first generation catalysts [81]. Recently the same group reported that Brønsted bases can decompose the metathesis-active Ru intermediates of Hoveyda and Grubbs second-generation catalysts [82]. Czeluśniak and coworkers reported a substrate mediated decomposition of phosphine free Grubbs systems for the cyclization and dimerization of the phenylacetylene [83,84]. Recently Cavallo and co-workers reported bond energies in the range 25–43 kcal/mol for several ruthenium olefin metathesis catalysts and proposed that such bond breaking event is possible for them [85,86]. Here the Ru-chloro bond cleavage is considered as a plausible decomposition pathway for the catalyst to generate a non-metathesis active species. The chloro ligand could migrate to the carbene carbon (defined by a transition state ts6) to get the catalytically active species k where Ru is in +2 oxidation state. This species with a 14e configuration resembles that of CpRuCl complex, well known for [2 + 2 + 2] type cycloadditions with diynes and nitriles [25]. The Ru-chloro bond cleavage creates a vacant site for the alkyne to coordinate with Ru in a distorted trigonal pyramidal configuration. The chloro ligand migration to carbene carbon elongates the RuCα bond by ∼0.13 Å indicating single bond character of the bond and loss of metathesis activity of the complex. For all the catalyst models (1–4), the transformed k type species are used for exploring the cyclotrimerization pathway given in Scheme 1. Such a pathway is well known in the case of CpRuCl, reported by Yamamoto et al. [25] In the non-metathesis pathway for 1 (Fig. 4 ), coordination of the first alkyne unit occurs on 1k to yield 1l. In the next step, RuO bond cleavage (1m) promotes the coordination of the second alkyne unit to Ru (1n). The next stage of the reaction describes an intramolecular [2 + 2] cycloaddition between the coordinated alkyne units in 1n via 1ts7 leading to the formation of a stable ruthenacyclopentadiene intermediate 1o. At this stage, coordination of acetonitrile to Ru is invoked (1p). Subsequently, CC bond coupling occurs between acetonitrile and Cα of metallacyclopentadiene through the transition state 1ts8 which give rise to the formation of a [3.2.0] bicyclic ring 1q. This intermediate opens up at the central RuC bond through 1ts9 to a seven-memberd metallacycle 1r. 1r undergoes ring contraction reaction by promoting NC bond formation via 1ts10. The desired heterocyclic product is formed from this transition state which shows coordination of the piridyl nitrogen to ruthenium. During this process, the chloro ligand migrates back to ruthenium to regenerate the catalytically active species. Reaction pathway similar to 1 is observed for the cyclotrimerization reaction catalyzed by Grubbs second generation catalyst 2 and smaller catalyst models 3 and 4. Various intermediates and transition states of the reaction pathways for 2, 3 and 4 are depicted in the Supplementary Material. The relative free energy profiles for the non-metathesis pathway catalyzed by all four catalysts are given in Fig. 5 . Chloro migration from the metal center to the carbene carbon requires 40.8 and 40.2 kcal/mol respectively for 1 and 2. The smaller Hoveyda-Grubbs-type catalyst 3 requires 38.7 kcal/mol for the chloro migration while an activation barrier of 24.1 kcal/mol is observed for catalyst transformation in 4. These barrier heights indicate that the non-metathesis pathway needs severe reaction conditions except for 4. Also, the modified catalyst k for Grubbs second generation catalyst 2 and 4 appears more stable than that obtained for 1 and 3. Alkyne coordination to the metal center slightly stabilizes the catalyst systems in the case of 1 and 3 while slight destabilization is observed for 2 and 4 due to steric influence from phosphine ligand. Further, dissociation of the labile ligand from complex l (Ru-O bond cleavage for 1 and 3 and phosphine ligand dissociation for 2 and 4) occurs spontaneously with lowering of free energy for all the catalysts except 4 that reduces the steric crowding around the metal. In 4l, ligand dissociation is energy demanding by 6.2 kcal/mol while sterically most crowded 2l shows a large drop in free energy. Activation barrier for the CC bond coupling (ts7) is in the range of 3.8–9.4 kcal/mol for all catalyst models. The CC coupling via ts7 results in a stable ruthenacyclopentadiene intermediate (o). Coordination of nitrile causes a slight increase in free energy for 1 and 3. Activation barrier for the coupling between RuC and CN bond (ts8) requires 27.8 and 20.3 kcal/mol for Hoveyda-Grubbs-type catalysts 1 and 3 while the value is 15.6 and 15.2 kcal/mol respectively for 2 and 4. The activation barrier for the final CN coupling in r is 21.2, 19.8, 20.1, 18.8 kcal/mol respectively for 1, 2, 3 and 4. Most commonly known decomposition pathway discussed by Grubbs and group involves a phosphine ligand migration to the carbene carbon instead of the chloro ligand [49]. In order to check this we compared the phosphine ligand migration with chloro ligand migration for Grubbs second generation catalysts 2 and 4, and found that chloro ligand migration is in fact comparable with that of the phosphine migration (supplementary material). Both metathesis and non-metathesis pathways suggest that smaller versions of the catalysts are good choice for the cyclotrimerization reaction. Both 3 and 4, the smaller versions of the Hoveyda-Grubbs and Grubbs second generation catalysts, respectively show relatively lower activation free energy in both metathesis and non-metathesis pathways. Comparison of reaction profiles in Fig. 3 (metathesis) and Fig. 5 (non-metathesis) may suggest that metathesis is the obvious choice for describing the pyridine ring formation. However, by invoking the possibility that the catalyst undergoes decomposition at the condition used for the reaction, viz. 90 °C by Pérez-Castells et al., the metathesis pathway may be ruled out. Otherwise, the chances for formation of benzene derivative is higher than the pyridine ring formation. We looked at this alternate possibility by proposing the coordination of a second diyne with metal center in 1f instead of the coordination of acetonitrile. Such a pathway showed the facile formation of the CC bond with activation free energy 7.4 kcal/mol (Supplementary Material) which is 18.2 kcal/mol lower than the CC bond formation via the coordination of acetonitrile (1ts3). In fact, this pathway explains the formation of the carbocycle (a benzene derivative) byproduct reported by Pérez-Castells et al. It may be noted that the alternate pathway suggests the use of excess diyne while the actual reaction conditions used excess amount of activated nitrile (5 equivalents with respect to diyne concentration) which is favorable for the non-metathesis pathway at 90 °C. An alternate non-metathesis pathway for the byproduct formation is not observed. 4 Conclusions The cyclotrimerization between diyne and acetonitrile is a highly exothermic reaction which involves the conversion of triple bonds to aromatic bonds. Both Hoveyda-Grubbs and Grubbs second generation catalysts and their simpler versions show metathesis and non-metathesis pathways for the cyclotrimerization. The bulky mesityl group as well as the isopropoxy group influence the stability of the intermediates and thus play a vital role in the mechanism. In metathesis pathway of 1 and 2, the second step yields a Hoveyda-type catalyst and subsequently the second alkyne unit coordinates to the metal by the loss of RuO bond. When the mesityl groups in 1 and 2 is replaced by methyl groups (3 and 4), second alkyne coordination occurs without the intervention of the oxygen coordinated species. In general, metathesis pathway follows Scheme 2 where the rate determining step is the CC bond formation between the coordinated acetonitrile and the carbene center of the catalyst. For non-metathesis pathway, the catalytically active species is generated by migrating the chloro ligand to the carbene center. The resulting species is metathesis inactive while the creation of a vacant coordination on Ru promotes the coordination of the first alkyne unit and subsequent reactions thereafter as per Scheme 1. Here the proposed ruthenium carbon bond inactivation for non-metathesis requires higher energy for catalysts 1 and 2 with bulky mesityl group on the NHC than their smaller versions. In all cases, the first step leading to catalyst transformation emerges as the most crucial for non-metathesis activity. Decreasing the bulkiness of the NHC ligand enhances both the metathesis and non-metathesis pathways of cyclotrimerization. Typically pyridine ring formation reactions are done at high temperature with excess amount of activated nitriles. If the catalyst is not decomposed under such circumstances, only a metathesis pathway can be invoked for the formation of the heterocycle because the more facile route to benzene ring formation may be suppressed by the excess amount of nitrile present in the reaction. In such a pathway, the CC coupling from the nitrile coordinated complex (1g) will be the rate determining step. If the catalyst undergoes decomposition, the non-metathesis pathway has to be invoked to describe the outcome of the reaction. Hence we feel that it is very important to find out experimentally the nature of the active catalytic species in the reaction to make further progress in the design of efficient catalysts for pyridine synthesis. coredata.dc:description: The [2 + 2 + 2] cyclotrimerization of diynes and nitrile provides an efficient method for the synthesis of pyridine and its derivatives which can be extended in the total synthesis of natural products. Use of Grubbs type ruthenium catalysts in the cyclotrimerization reaction expands the applicability of Ru(II) catalysts. Two plausible pathways, viz. metathesis and non-metathesis for the cyclotrimerization reaction between a diyne and a nitrile are elucidated with Grubbs second generation and Hoveyda-Grubbs catalysts using DFT techniques. A ruthenacyclobutene like complex is obtained as a stable intermediate in the metathesis pathway while the formation of a five membered metallacycle is invoked to explain the non-metathesis pathway using a decomposed catalyst. The study reveals the influence of N-substituents on N-heterocyclic ligands (NHC) as well as substituent on carbene ligand in controlling the energetic of both metathesis and non-metathesis pathways. Incorporating NHC ligand with reduced steric influence in catalyst design is desirable for improving the efficiency of cyclotrimerization reaction of alkynes with nitriles. If the catalyst is not decomposed, metathesis is the reaction route and the preferred product will be a benzene derivative. The heterocycle formation observed by Pérez-Castells et al. (Org. Lett., 14, 2012, 4982–4985) in presence of excess activated nitriles can only be described using the decomposed catalyst through a non-metathesis pathway.
coredata.dc:title: Grubbs and Hoveyda-Grubbs catalysts for pyridine derivative synthesis: Probing the mechanistic pathways using DFT
